title: Traffic Analysis Practices for Non-Motorized Modes (Vulnerable Road Users)
description: The objective of this synthesis is to document the current state of the traffic analysis practice (not limited to the deterministic methods such as HCM) for non-motorized modes (or multimodal analysis).

title: Predicting Field Performance of Pavement Markings Statewide in Texas
description: This project will explore various factors that affect pavement marking performance over the service life of the marking (pavement marking materials, installation specifications, pavement surface, traffic conditions, and geographic and climatic region) to develop performance models for Texas. Performance of a variety of markings and markers will be evaluated at various field test areas.

title: Improve Safety and Decrease Vehicle Fatalities by Improving Pavement Markings
description: The main objective of this project is to improve roadway safety by evaluating and maintaining pavement markings, including retroreflective markers, in selected roadways. The goal is to assess their condition, renew markings as needed, and determine if these efforts reduce vehicle fatalities and crashes.

title: Analyze Operational and Safety Improvements Associated with Implemented Innovative Intersections in Texas
description: The objective of this project is to document the benefits of innovative intersection designs, develop case studies of successfully implemented intersections in Texas, and provide resources to support the adoption and implementation of these designs across the state.

title: Develop Crash Predictive Methods for Frontage Roads Including Ramp Terminals, and Intersections with Crossroads in Texas
description: The objective of this project is to develop Safety Performance Functions (SPFs) and Crash Modification Factors (CMFs) for ramp terminals and frontage road intersections, evaluate the safety impact of weaving on frontage roads versus freeways, and create crash predictive models tailored to different area types, regions, and facility types. The project also aims to provide guidance on the configuration of frontage road segments, intersections, and appropriate spacing between ramps, intersections, and driveways.

title: Identification of Unprecedented Coastal Flooding Hotspots for Highway Network Durability and Social Justice
description: The objective of this project is to develop a comprehensive framework and toolsets for evaluating coastal flood risks and assessing highway network durability using AI-based flood models, hydrodynamic simulations, and road risk scoring. The project also aims to enhance flood hazard mapping, uncover social vulnerability in transportation systems, and transfer research outcomes to practical operations for public benefit.

title: Social and Community Factors Contributing to Pedestrian Trespass Behaviors (and Motorist Incursions) on Railroad Systems
Roadside Feature Placement and Pedestrian Safety on Low and Intermediate Speed Roads
description: The objective of this study is to provide empirical models and evidence to help designers balance complete streets principles with roadside safety on low- and intermediate-speed urban roads. It aims to address the effectiveness of lateral offsets in reducing fixed-object crashes and explore how roadside infrastructure, such as trees, influences driver behavior and operating speeds.

title: Incorporating Safe System Approach into the NCHRP 500 Series
description: The objective of this project is to develop a searchable electronic toolkit that updates and expands the NCHRP Report 500 series to align with Safe System principles and AASHTO's current priorities. The toolkit will incorporate the latest research and innovations to support transportation officials in selecting evidence-based countermeasures for various crash types, improve usability, and advance the implementation of the Safe System approach to help achieve the goal of zero road fatalities.

title: Increasing Equity in Traffic Safety, AAA Foundation
SafeR: The Safest Routing Tool
Develop Crash Modification Factors for Super 2 Highways
description: The objective of this project is to develop updated Crash Modification Factors (CMFs) for Super 2 highways in Texas by analyzing recent crash data and site characteristics. The results will help TxDOT and other practitioners make informed decisions about installing future Super 2 corridors, providing additional safety support and complementing existing guidance. The CMFs will also be submitted to the FHWA's CMF Clearinghouse for inclusion in their database.

title: Exploring and Developing Innovative Methods for Estimating VMT on Local Roads in Texas
description: The objective of this project is to develop and validate data-driven methods for estimating vehicle miles traveled (VMT) on local roads in Texas. These methods aim to provide more accurate and cost-effective VMT estimates, reducing potential bias and financial challenges associated with conducting short-term traffic counts, while offering significant savings to the Texas Department of Transportation.

title: Safety Assessment of Shared use Paths at Roadway Crossings using Exposure-based Models
description: The objective of this project is to assess safety concerns at shared use path (SUP) roadway crossings involving pedestrians, bicyclists, micromobility users, and people with disabilities. The project aims to develop design and planning guidance for selecting appropriate treatments, considering different types of users, road classifications, land-use contexts, and crossing geometries, including paths next to railroads. This will support the safe implementation of SUPs across Texas.

title: Barrier Striping for the reduction of accidents
description: The objective of this project is to evaluate the long-term and short-term safety effectiveness of retroreflective solid stripe applications on concrete barriers by analyzing before-and-after collision and near-collision data. The research also involves installing the treatments at six high-crash locations with various barrier types to assess their short-term impact. The findings will be used to update the special specification (SS) drafted by TxDOT's Traffic Safety Division for wider future use.

title: SafeR: The Safest Routing Tool
Evaluation of NJDOT Hardened Traffic Paint Markings and Stripes Performance
description: The objective of this project is to evaluate the performance of various pavement marking materials in relation to visibility, durability, and compatibility with autonomous vehicle systems. The study aims to analyze technical and performance data, address issues such as drying time, durability, and supply chain challenges, and provide recommendations for improving marking installation, maintenance practices, and specifications. The goal is to enhance road marking performance under varying conditions, ensuring visibility for both human drivers and automated driving systems.

title: Develop a Real-Time Decision Support Tool for Urban Roadway Safety Improvement
description: The objective of this project is to develop updated Safety Performance Functions (SPFs) for urban roadways and create a real-time decision support tool for risk scoring, incorporating speed, short-duration traffic volume, and weather data from national databases. This tool will provide a dynamic model updating pipeline to improve urban roadway safety, addressing the increased fatality rates and enhancing decision-making for transportation agencies.

title: Leveraging Artificial Intelligence (AI) Techniques to Detect, Forecast, and Manage Freeway Congestion
description: The objective of this project is to enhance the quality and efficiency of Texas' surface transportation system by leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) to predict and manage congestion. The project involves verifying the reliability of commercial data sources, identifying effective AI models for transportation needs, and developing a GIS-based decision support tool to aid decision-makers in prioritizing resources and implementing tailored congestion management strategies across various freeway segments.

title: Using Vehicle Probe Data to Evaluate Speed Limits on Texas Highways
description: The objective of this project is to explore the use of vehicle probe data and other big datasets to streamline the process of conducting speed limit studies for TxDOT. The goal is to reduce the effort and time required to collect speed data, provide a safer method for data collection, and develop procedures for using probe speed information to produce speed limit recommendations that align with TxDOT's current engineering practices. This will help TxDOT districts become more proactive and responsive in their speed zone programs.

title: Developing AI-driven Safe Navigation Tool
description: The objective of this study is to develop a real-time navigation system that provides data-driven decisions on the safest route by leveraging historical and real-time data sources. The tool integrates safety, distance, travel time, and other scoring factors using advanced AI algorithms to offer users informed route options, enhancing road safety and improving the reliability of navigation compared to existing applications that only focus on distance or travel time.

title: Uses of Social Media in Public Transportation
description: The objective of the study presented in this PDF is to analyze how transit agencies use social media to communicate with their audiences. The study aims to document innovative and effective practices, explore the reasons transit agencies use social media, identify the platforms used, measure social media effectiveness, and provide resources and strategies for improving transit agency engagement with the public.

title: Safety Enhancements at Short-Storage-Space Railroad Crossings
description: The objective of this project is to provide guidance on short-storage railroad crossings in Michigan by examining crash data, driver behavior, and environmental factors to identify suitable safety countermeasures. The project aims to refine guidelines through collaboration between MDOT Traffic & Safety and the Office of Rail, ultimately improving safety at short-storage crossings through data analysis, driver behavior studies, and recommendations for relevant MDOT publications.

title: Autonomous Delivery Vehicle as a Disruptive Technology: How to Shape the Future with a Focus on Safety?
description: The objective of this study is to understand and analyze the safety-related issues and impacts of low-speed autonomous delivery vehicles (ADVs). The study performed safety implication and safety impact analyses using alternative datasets due to the lack of large-scale vehicle movement data from ADV operators. The research employed association rules mining to identify risk patterns, providing benchmarks for reducing risks in ADV deployments compared to human-driven trips.

title: Develop a Real-Time Decision Support Tool for Rural Roadway Safety Improvements
description: The objective of this project is to reduce rural roadway crashes, specifically focusing on roadway departure and speeding-related crashes, by developing updated safety performance functions and a decision support tool. The research combines real-time speed, volume, and weather data from national databases to enhance crash risk analysis and support TxDOT's future vision plans for improving rural roadway safety.

title: Develop Speed Crash Modification Factors (CMFs) from SHRP-2 Data
description: The objective of this project is to develop speed-related Crash Modification Factors (CMFs) for 12 different roadway facility types, including rural highways, urban and suburban arterials, and freeways. By using data from Washington and North Carolina, the project aims to improve the precision of crash prediction models by incorporating speed variation and speed differential measures. The CMFs provide a data-driven approach for evaluating speed-related crashes, which can be applied in various states to enhance roadway safety analysis.

title: Use of Disruptive Technologies to Support Safety Analysis and Meet New Federal Requirements
description: The objective of this project is to assess the accuracy of alternative data sources for estimating annual average daily traffic (AADT) on non-federal aid system (NFAS) roads and to evaluate the impact of AADT on safety analysis. The research aims to compare AADT estimates from traditional methods with probe-based estimates, develop safety performance functions (SPFs), and perform sensitivity analysis to understand how AADT affects safety outcomes using the empirical Bayes method.

title: Core Competencies for Key Safety Analysis
description: The objective of the project is to compile a comprehensive synthesis of research on education and training opportunities related to core competencies in safety analysis. The project aims to develop a user-friendly tool that allows transportation agencies to assess their workforce development needs effectively. Additionally, the project provides a template for highway agencies to identify efficient and effective education and training programs, ensuring that their staff are equipped with the necessary skills and knowledge for conducting safety analysis.

title: Comparison of Cost, Safety, and Environmental Benefits of Routine Mowing and Managed Succession of Roadside Vegetation
description: The objective of the project is to provide guidance for roadside vegetation management by comparing the costs, safety, and environmental impacts of routine mowing with managed vegetation succession outside the safety clear zone. The project aims to help DOTs re-evaluate their roadside management practices to balance environmental benefits, such as stormwater management, carbon sequestration, and habitat conservation, with cost savings and safety improvements for maintenance personnel.
